toLevel2.question: What is the heat of combustion of fats and oils?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Fats and oils release 37 kJ per gram when completely combusted, the highest energy density of the three macronutrient groups.

distractors.explanation: 17 kJ g⁻¹ is the value for proteins, not fats. Fats release 37 kJ g⁻¹.
16 kJ g⁻¹ is the value for carbohydrates. Fats release 37 kJ g⁻¹.
This is not a standard reference value. Fats release 37 kJ g⁻¹.

16 kJ g⁻¹ is the value for carbohydrates. Proteins release 17 kJ g⁻¹.
This is not a standard reference value. Proteins release 17 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel2.question: What is the heat of combustion of carbohydrates?

toLevel2.question: Which food group releases the most energy per gram when combusted?

distractors.explanation: Proteins release 17 kJ g⁻¹, far less than fats at 37 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel2.question: What units are used for the heat of combustion of food groups?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Food energy values are expressed in kilojoules per gram (kJ g⁻¹) because foods are mixtures of molecules with varying molar masses.

distractors.explanation: kJ mol⁻¹ is used for pure fuels, not food groups. Foods use kJ g⁻¹ because they are mixtures.
Food energy values use kilojoules (kJ), not joules (J) per gram.
kJ L⁻¹ is not the standard unit for food energy; kJ g⁻¹ is used.

toLevel3.question: Why do fats release more energy per gram than carbohydrates?
